journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Turbulence and additive effects on ignition delay in supersonic combustion

article-meta.aff: Aerospace Engineering Department, Sharif University of Technology, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Amir M Tahsini, Aerospace Research Institute, 15th Alley, Mahestan Street, Ghods Square, Tehran, Iran. Email: a_m_tahsini@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Numerical study of two-dimensional supersonic hydrogen–air mixing layer is performed to investigate the effects of turbulence and chemical additive on ignition distance. Chemical reaction is treated using detail kinetics. Advection upstream splitting method is used to calculate the fluxes, and one-equation turbulence model is chosen here to simulate the considered problem. Hydrogen peroxide is used as an additive and the results show that inflow turbulence and chemical additive may drastically decrease the ignition delay in supersonic combustion.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The interests in the development of propulsion system for high-speed vehicles as scramjets have led to extensive studies of supersonic combustion phenomena up to now. However, these studies confront many unresolved problems and much research remains to be done. One of the principal difficulties encountered has arisen from the flow residence times being of the same order of magnitude as the ignition delay time within the combustion chamber. Rapid ignition process as well as fast and complete combustion is significant to decrease combustor length and weight in this situation. On a physical viewpoint, ignition within a supersonic flow gives rise to problems related to the coupling between chemical kinetics and compressible, high-temperature, turbulence fluid dynamics. On the other hand, the flow dynamics in an actual combustor is rather intricate due to various flow structures, and shock wave interactions arise from complex geometry. So, the reacting mixing layer established between two parallel fuel–air streams was quite attractive for fundamental studies been done, as described below.

Ju and Niioka1 have made analytical study on the ignition of a laminar, two-dimensional, supersonic mixing layer of parallel streams of unpremixed oxidant and fuel, using a three-step reaction kinetics to predict the ignition distance and the effects of free shear, Mach number, and reaction rates on the ignition distance. They have also numerically predicted the ignition distances for hydrogen–air and methane–air laminar mixing layers using reduced kinetic mechanism.2,3 Da Silva et al.4 have numerically investigated the effects of initial temperature and velocity gradients on ignition distance in supersonic laminar hydrogen–air mixing layer and found that the flame always starts from the airside and the triple flame structure is not present in cases studied. Im et al.5 have asymptotically analyzed the thermal ignition behavior in laminar supersonic mixing layer using one-step overall reaction and reported that the ignition distance, for the case where the speed of the air stream is greater than that of the hydrogen, first increases as the Mach number increases. But it decreases with further increase in Mach number by virtue of the increase in temperature in the mixing layer because of friction-generated heat. They also have repeated this study using reduced reaction mechanism.6 Nishioka and Law7 have numerically studied the temperature effect on ignition in supersonic laminar hydrogen–air mixing layer using detail chemistry and found that there is a lower limit of the air stream temperature below which ignition in a scramjet combustor is not possible and at higher temperatures, radical proliferation rather than thermal runaway causes ignition. Fang et al.8 have numerically investigated the effect of initial pressure on ignition distance in supersonic laminar mixing layer in the presence of a pressure gradient. Tien and Stalker9 have computationally studied the effect of the initial conditions on the ignition distance in supersonic laminar hydrogen–air mixing layer using detail chemical kinetics and showed that the initial oxygen atom concentration has serious effect on ignition delay.

There are few research works reporting such studies in the presence of turbulent phenomena. Chakraborty et al.10 have investigated the supersonic turbulent reacting mixing layer using various empirical direct numerical simulation data. Zambon et al.11 have numerically predicted the ignition distance in supersonic turbulent mixing layer using automatic reduction procedure chemical kinetics, for various splitter lip thicknesses.

As it is clear, ignition distance estimation is one of the most important purposes in scramjet study and design, and it is favorite to reduce it. Zabaikin et al.12 have experimentally investigated the effect of hydrogen peroxide addition on ignition and combustion in supersonic hydrogen–air flow and found that it becomes possible to decrease abruptly the ignition delay, improve the flame stability, and increase the combustion efficiency using small amounts of chemically active additives.

In this study, the supersonic turbulent hydrogen–air mixing layer is analyzed numerically using detail chemical kinetics. The effects of various parameters such as flow turbulence level, the presence of water vapor in air flow, and hydrogen peroxide addition on ignition location are predicted and discussed.

sec.title: Governing equations and numerical method
sec.p: According to the considered problem (supersonic combustion in a mixing layer), the two-dimensional Reynolds-averaged compressible Navier–Stokes equations governing the continuum flow representing the conservation of mass, momentum, energy, and species are used. The conservation equations are written in the following form13 (1)∂U∂t+∂g(F+Fvg)∂x+∂g(G+Gvg)∂y=ST U=g[ρρuρvρeρmjg]F=g[ρuρuu+pρuvρuhρumjg] G=g[ρvρvuρvv+pρvhρvmjg] (2)Fv=g[0-τxx-τxyqx-uτxx-vτxyρDeffmxg]Gv=g[0-τyx-τyyqy-uτyx-vτyyρDeffmyg]ST=g[0000ω·jg] (3)τxx=μeffg(2∂u∂x-23∇.Vg)τxy=μeffg(∂u∂y+∂v∂xg)τyy=μeffg(2∂v∂y-23∇.Vg) (4)μeff=μ+μte=cvT+g(uu+vvg)/2+∑mjΔhf,joq=-keff∇T-ρDeff∑hi∇mihi=Δhf,io+∫cpidT

The turbulence model used to close the system of equations is the Spalart–Allmaras model.14 This is a one-equation model assembled using empiricism and arguments of dimensional analysis, Galilean invariance, and selective dependence on the molecular viscosity. The eddy viscosity is determined through a partial differential equation as follows (5)Dg(ν~g)Dt=cb1S~ν~+1σg[∇.g(g(ν+ν~g)∇ν~g)+cb2g(∇ν~g)2g]-cw1fwg(ν~dg)2

This equation is solved for the variable ν~ and the eddy viscosity is calculated as νt=ν~fv1, where the function fv1 is a damping function which is used to treat the buffer layer and the viscous sublayer (6)S~=S+g(ν~/κ2d2g)fv2fv2=1-X/g(1+Xfv1g)fv1=X3/g(X3+cv13g)X=ν~/ν Here, d is the distance to the closest wall, S the magnitude of vorticity, and S~ the modified strain rate. The function fw is given as (7)fw=gg(1+cw36g6+cw36g)16 where (8)g=z+cw2g(z6-zg)z=ν~S~κ2d2 The constants are cb1=0.1355,cb2=0.622,cv1=7.1σ=2/3,cw1=3.239,cw2=0.3cw3=2,κ=0.41 Equation (5) is solved coupled with flow governing equations.

The finite-rate reaction model (Table 1) which was given by Stahl and Warnatz is employed here as a full chemistry for hydrogen–air combustion.15 There are nine chemical species within the reaction mechanism; so, eight conservation equations for species should be considered besides one overall mass fraction equation. Therefore, there are 13 coupled equations to be solved in flow field. Table 1.

22 H2O+O → HO2+H 2.95E13 0.00 244.51
23 HO2+O → OH+O2 1.80E13 0.00 −1.70
24 OH+O2 → HO2+O 2.30E13 0.00 231.71
25 HO2+OH → H2O+O2 6.00E13 0.00 0.00
26 H2O+O2 → HO2+OH 7.52E14 0.00 304.09
27 HO2+HO2 → H2O2+O2 2.50E11 0.00 −5.20
28 OH+OH+M* → H2O2+M* 3.25E22 −2.00 0.00
29 H2O2+M* → OH+OH+M* 1.69E24 −2.00 202.29
30 H2O2+H → H2+HO2 1.70E12 0.00 15.70
31 H2+HO2 → H2O2+H 1.32E12 0.00 83.59
32 H2O2+H → H2O+OH 1.00E13 0.00 15.00
33 H2O+OH → H2O2+H 3.34E12 0.00 312.19
34 H2O2+O → OH+HO2 2.80E13 0.00 26.80
35 OH+HO2 → H2O2+O 9.51E12 0.00 86.68
36 H2O2+OH → H2O+HO2 5.40E12 0.00 4.20
37 H2O+HO2 → H2O2+OH 1.80E13 0.00 134.75

Cell-centered based finite volume method is used to discrete the governing equations. The time integration is accomplished by an explicit time stepping scheme.16 Viscous terms are calculated using a central scheme and inviscid terms are treated using an advection upstream splitting method to express the numerical flux at cell faces.17 This method is one of the most recent developed ones which is faster than the famous Roe’s scheme and has following features: Positivity-preserving property, improvement in accuracy, simplicity, and easy generalization to other conservation laws. The present simulation program has been validated using a variety of benchmark problems and used successfully to study the solid fuel ignition in turbulent flows.18–20

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
At first, the focus is on the problem examined by Ju and Niioka,2 the auto-ignition process within the laminar mixing layer between a supersonic air stream and a hydrogen stream diluted by nitrogen neutral gas (Figure 1). Dimensions of the physical domain are length 16 cm length and 1 cm height. Figure 1.
Schematic configuration of problem.

At Tair = TH2 = 1200 K and Mair = 1.84 and MH2 = 1.2, the ignition distance was reported 9.6 cm downstream of the splitter. To study this problem, the 200 × 70 grids are used along axial and lateral directions in which the grids are stretched in central axis of flow to study the mixing layer carefully. The selected mesh is used here after proper grid independency studies. The present simulation has exact agreement with Ju and Niioka.2 Temperature distribution along splitter is shown in Figure 2 and temperature contours show the flame position in flow field in Figure 3. It emphasizes again the validity of the present numerical procedure. In this study, the inflexion point on the curve of water vapor concentration is used as a criterion of ignition.3 Figure 2.
Temperature along splitter.
Figure 3.
Flame position.

As mentioned earlier, ignition location is an important subject in supersonic combustion propulsion systems and its reduction will help scaling down the scramjets. Some effective parameters on this subject arestudied here.

sec.title: Inflow turbulence
sec.p:
The problem under consideration has a turbulence transition distance longer than the specified geometry.21 So, the turbulence effect generated inside is not important here. The focus is on the inflow turbulence influence. To study this, the ignition simulation is re-examined using various inflow turbulence levels. The results show that increasing the turbulence level up to certain level (eddy viscosity of about 0.0015 for this situation) decreases the ignition distance about 15% and amplifies the flame thickness. But more than this level, it just increases the flame thickness and has no effect on ignition delay. Figure 4 displays the ignition location versus inflow turbulence. Figure 5 illustrates the flame thickness increment by the lateral distribution of temperature at a position of 3 cm downstream of the ignition location. Flame widening is appropriate to avoid combustion instabilities in propulsion systems achieved here by inflow turbulence. Figure 4.
Ignition distance variation due to inlet turbulence.
Figure 5.
Flame expanding due to inlet turbulence.

Increasing an inlet turbulence level apparently increases the fuel and oxidizer mixing due to turbulent mass and viscous diffusion rates and decreases the lateral mixing time scale, so decreases the ignition distance for lower turbulence levels. In higher turbulence levels, the axial time scale (due to Damkohler number) controls the ignition distance; so, the turbulence just affects the flame thickness.

sec.title: Hydrogen peroxide additive
sec.p:
Using hydrogen peroxide as an additive has intense influence on ignition delay reduction. It is shown here by adding a little H2O2 to flow in different three ways: First by adding it to fuel flow instead of nitrogen, then adding it to fuel instead of hydrogen, and finally adding it to air instead of nitrogen up to 1%. Ignition distance variation versus H2O2 mass fraction is presented in Figure 6. The results show that it is not important to add the additive instead of which species, but the addition to air has more effect than fuel flow. Furthermore, although a little hydrogen peroxide addition decreases suddenly the ignition delay, increasing its mass fraction slowly continues this reduction. Figure 6.
Ignition distance variation due to H2O2 addition.

Adding hydrogen peroxide in such high-temperature flows apparently accelerates the elementary chemical reactions due to higher generation of free radicals such as O and OH ions according to its chemical instability, therefore decreases the ignition distance effectively. Hydrogen peroxide unlike many other additives is less toxic and used in many other technologies so will be used as a proper material in supersonic combustion.

sec.title: Inflow water vapor
sec.p:
Presence of the water vapor within inflow air may alter the ignition process in propulsion with air intake such as scramjets. Adding a little vapor in air increases the ignition distance as expected primarily which is not favorable. It is shown that there is about 25% increments in ignition distance due to a little vapor in inlet air flow (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Ignition distance versus vapor mass fraction in air flow.

Water vapor value cannot be controlled easily at air inlet and its effect could be estimated in analysis and design. But inflow turbulence and using additive may apply to decrease the ignition delay in scramjets. For example, using an inlet eddy viscosity of 0.001 and adding 0.1% hydrogen peroxide to air decreases the ignition distance from initial 9.6 cm to 3.7 cm which is a significant reduction. Figure 8 illustrates this by flame position in flow field. Figure 8.
Flame position: (a) base flow and (b) turbulent flow with chemical additive.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, the ignition of hydrogen–air supersonic mixing layer is numerically analyzed using detail chemistry. Attention is paid to the ignition distance estimation and reduction by inflow turbulence level and hydrogen peroxide addition. It is shown that the increasing turbulence level decreases the ignition distance and widens the flame up to a certain level, but more than it just increases the flame thickness which is favorable according to combustion stability. Adding H2O2 to airor fuel flow decreases the ignition delay significantly and adding it to air flow is more appropriate. Also, presence of water vapor in air inlet increases the ignition distance which is unfavorable. The results show that increasing the inlet turbulence level and using a little H2O2 may decrease the ignition distance for about a third of initial value in a mixing layer.

mass rate of production of species j
